title: Caitlin Swalec
text:
About Me
I am passionate about industrial decarbonization as a solution for a livable future on the planet I love to explore. I direct the Heavy Industry Program at Global Energy Monitor, a nonprofit research organization, and teach carbon accounting at the graduate-level at the University of California, Santa Barbara. My favorite ways to travel and explore our world are through open water swimming and trail running. You could say that I’m pursuing a high-carb lifestyle on a low-carb(on) planet.



Current Position
Program Director for Heavy Industry | Global Energy Monitor

Pitched and secured over $1.75 million USD annually in funding for research initiatives in GEM’s heavy industry program.
Managing a team of 10 project managers and researchers working to drive climate change action in the iron and steel, cement and concrete, and iron ore mining sectors.
Developed and launched datasets on global iron and steel production in order to support the industrial decarbonization movement.

title: Experience and Skills
text: I have over 10 years of experience researching climate change and energy topics, with the last 5 years focused on heavy industry decarbonization, especially iron and steel. A summary of my professional skills are listed below. For my complete professional and academic experience, please download my CV.

title: Experience and Skills
text:
Professional Skills







Leadership
Experience as a supervisor, lead fundraiser and grant manager, hiring lead, project manager, and mentor for more than ten supervisees ranging from entry-level to PhD qualifications.


Communica-tions and media
Regular contact with and experience communicating complex technical topics to journalists and reporters from outlets including CNN, the Financial Times, DW, South China Morning Post, Fastmarkets, and Canary Media. Publications in industry newsletters and journals including GreenBiz, RENEW-Industry, and Steel Times International.


Fundraising
Pitched and secured over $1.75 million USD annually in funding for research initiatives in GEM’s Heavy Industry Program.


Engineering
Training and professional experience in air quality control and permitting, offshore windfarm planning, and chemical and industrial plant design. Strong understanding and appreciation for the practical challenges and opportunities of engineering and design, especially for climate change technologies.


Endurance
Demonstrated resilience, persistence, and positivity in the face of difficult tasks, including a 12-mile channel swim in the Pacific Ocean, a 50 mile run back and forth across the Grand Canyon, multiple marathon and ultramarathon length running races, and daily efforts to document and hold accountable emissions from the heavy industry sector.

title: Contact
text: For inquiries related to my work at Global Energy Monitor, please reach contact me through my work email (caitlin.swalec@globalenergymonitor.org). For all other inquiries, please email me personally (caitlin.swalec@gmail.com).

title: education
text:
Education
Master’s of Environmental Science and Management | University of California, Santa Barbara | 2017-2019
Specialized in energy and climate change technology and policy including coursework in carbon accounting, advanced energy technologies, environmental policy, and environmental communications. Led projects in offshore wind farm planning, wildfire management and permitting, and waste management.
B.S in Chemical Engineering | Worcester Polytechnic Institute | 2012-2016
Completed labs and coursework in chemical and industrial plant design, unit operations, air quality management, water and wastewater engineering, power engineering, and environmental design and theory. Gained global experience through work and studies in Germany, France, Thailand, and the United States.
Continuous learning | Ongoing
Engaged as a continuous learner through the  Managing to Change the World training from The Management Center (2024), a certification in Lifecycle Assessment from the American Institute of Chemical Engineers (2023), and a course on the New Hydrogen Economy from Terra.do (2021).

title: Personal Projects
text: My professional work on the climate movement is fueled by my personal passions for trail running, open water swimming, and fiber arts. While seeking adventure, discovery, and creation through these activities, I feel deeply connected to our planet and my community.

title: Personal Projects
text:
Trail Running
My most recent trail running adventure was a 50 mile rim-to-rim-to-rim crossing of the Grand Canyon in Arizona, USA on October 9, 2024. The effort was solo, unassisted, and joyful. Four days later I ran the Chicago Marathon with one of my best friends.

title: Personal Projects
text:
Open Water Swimming
On October 3, 2023, I completed a 12.4 statute mile solo swim from Anacapa Island to Oxnard, California according to the marathon swimming rules of the Santa Barbara Channel Swimming Association. My swim was featured for a Waterwoman Wednesday by Women in the Water.

title: Personal Projects
text:
Fiber Arts
I enjoy knitting and crocheting and dream of one day having an entirely handmade closet of knitwear. I document my work on Ravelry and Instagram.
